subject: RE: [junit] JUnit 4
msgSnippet: Jason, Convenient usage of JUnit 4 test with older runners is one of our goals. Can you give me a specific example where a decorator would make this possible?
messageBody:
Jason,

Convenient usage of JUnit 4 test with older runners is one of our goals. Can
you give me a specific example where a decorator would make this possible?
AFAIK, IDEs look for subclasses of TestCase or classes implementing a static
suite() method to identify tests. A JUnit 4 test runner would also look for
classes that reference the @Test annotation. The JUnit4TestAdapter is there
to bridge the gap with older runners. It is a pain to have to copy and edit
the suite() method, but I don't see how a decorator would solve the problem
better.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Jason Rogers
> Sent: Thursday, June 16, 2005 6:38 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4
>
> Kent Beck wrote:
>
> > Robert,
> >
> > This is an interesting idea. It would be very powerful. I'm
> having trouble
> > understanding what you would use it for beyond what you can do with
> > @Before/@After and @BeforeClass and @AfterClass, though. Do
> you have an
> > example?
>
> A generic decorator pattern would also help those of us who are using
> IDEs that are behind the JUnit curve. For instance, until
> Eclipse adds
> support for JUnit4 we would have to add a suite() method to every new
> test class in order for it to run in the Eclipse JUnitRunner. With a
> generic decorator pattern it seems that it would be possible to
> automatically detect that a test is a JUnit4 test (but not
> wrapped in a
> JUnit4TestAdapter) and proxy it for the old-style runner.
